data.title: Masjid Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Pattani
meta_keywords: มัสยิดกรือเซะ
มัสยิดปิตูกรือบัน
data.meta_description: Masjid Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Pattani, Thailand South Thailand’s Krue Se mosque has become a symbol of a troubled region. Pattani was semi-autonomous Islamic Malay sultanate until annexed by Thailand in 1902. Krue Se Mosque (Malay: Masjid Kerisek / Kerisik, Kerisek, Krisek;[a] Keresik, Kresik, Kresek, Krue Se, Gresik; Thai: มัสยิดกรือเซะ, RTGS: Matsayit Kruese) also called Gresik Mosque, Pitu Krue-ban Mosque / Masjid Pintu Gerbang (Thai: มัสยิดปิตูกรือบัน) or Sultan Muzaffar Shah Mosque. Its construction may have begun in the 16th century believed ca. 1524 during the reign of Sultan Muzaffar Shah. The surviving structure features a mixture of Middle Eastern and European architectural styles. Ref.: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krue_Se_Mosque ms.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masjid_Kersik www.aljazeera.com/news/2007/10/3/the-scars-of-krue-se www.isranews.org/content-page/item/29000-lesson.html
data.text:
Masjid Sultan Muzaffar Shah, Pattani, Thailand

South Thailand’s Krue Se mosque has become a symbol of a troubled region. Pattani was semi-autonomous Islamic Malay sultanate until annexed by Thailand in 1902.

Krue Se Mosque (Malay: Masjid Kerisek / Kerisik, Kerisek, Krisek;[a] Keresik, Kresik, Kresek, Krue Se, Gresik; Thai: มัสยิดกรือเซะ, RTGS: Matsayit Kruese) also called Gresik Mosque, Pitu Krue-ban Mosque / Masjid Pintu Gerbang (Thai: มัสยิดปิตูกรือบัน) or Sultan Muzaffar Shah Mosque.

Its construction may have begun in the 16th century believed ca. 1524 during the reign of Sultan Muzaffar Shah. The surviving structure features a mixture of Middle Eastern and European architectural styles.

Ref.:

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krue_Se_Mosque
